During the winter and spring I have been driving past the Dry Sevier Lake in Millard County Utah.  When I would watch the wind blow the water and ice from side to side and then from end to end I thought that it was cool.  Only one thing it doesn't really have a source of rocks like Death Valley.  But the Lake is a lot larger than where you're at in your video.  The Dry Sevier Lake also has about a 4 inch crust and under that there's no real bottom.  It's been described as having the consistency of peanut butter.  The salt crust seals the moisture in.

Nice story. I'm surprised it took 99 years to solve this mystery. Just by observation of the tracks, and noticing that the rocks all seemed to move in the same direction, and by observing the shape of the track mark. I can tell the following. The rocks moved in wet conditions. The ground itself was not frozen solid, if  it was, the rocks wouldn't be able to move because they would be frozen in the ground. The rocks would need to be on top of frozen ice to be pushed, BUT if the rocks were on top of the ice they would not be making the tracks you see on the ground. I do know that wet surfaces can allow very heavy things to easily slide on a smooth polished surface. Wet muddy conditions where the ground is hard enough the rock doesn't sink into the mud, but wet enough can allow the rock to slide, and given a gentle push from the wind would allow the rocks to move. Even up hill which is stated in the video. By natural deduction one could infer that water and wind played a roll. It is interesting to see ice also played a roll in the moving rocks.

There are videos that show what are called "ice tsunamis" on the shores of Lake Winnipeg in the province of Manitoba, Canada. The ice is much thicker and it melts into a shape similar to icicles. Long, thin shards as opposed to melting in layers from top to bottom. The ice sheets stay intact until they hit land, and when the wind is blowing towards shore, that ice piles up and has to go somewhere as more ice is blown in behind it. It has even destroyed homes and cottages along the shoreline.

Here is a little curiosity that means nothing... Though I live in Ohio, I have been all over Death Valley. One day I traveled alone out to a remote part of Death Valley called The Devil's Golf Course. It isn't a real golf course. It is simply a place where the dried lakebed of Death Valley has some interesting formations. When I arrived there was no one there. The landscape is perfectly flat for miles in all directions. No trees, no shrubs. If anyone were within miles, they would be visible because there is nothing to hide behind. I realized that I could shout anything I wanted, yes, including obscenities, and I knew that if anyone could hear them, I would be able to see them. I realized that it was an unusual phenomenon outdoors, on dry ground.

Don't forget that as ice forms it expands . So as a thin sheet starts to form , it is being pushed by the ice that has expanded as it froze, right beside it . If the ice was formed in calm weather then the molecules of ice would be inline on the surface , so they would be very solidly reinforced by each other as they push . The expansion horizontally would amount to motion that was visible and strong enough to push rocks .
We all know how ice thawing and freezing again can create pot holes and crack cement foundations, split metal pipes . It also carved rivers and valleys and reshaped landscapes when glaciers formed during the ice age . Where glaciers stopped or retreated they left walls of rock deposits.
It's a force more powerful than hydraulics.
The wind idea is not as likely because the ice is thin, smooth and flat , there isn't much for the wind to grab .

I also remember that my buddy set the world record that day for a frisbee toss. He had brought a disc golf "frisbee" with him on our trip. We were on dual sport motorcycles. When we got up to the race track- we came up on the brutal Lippencott Mine road-it was a bit windy. Death Valley is a truely unique place that has very varied and unpredictable weather.Back to the story. So my buddy whips out the disc from his saddlebag and procedes to toss it, like a wheel, onto the playa. We had binoculars with us also. The disc began to roll and it NEVER stopped.!!! A few times as we watched through our binoculars it would wobble, like it was going to stop, then right itself and keep on going. One less mystery to keep me up at night.

A fresh breeze pushed the winter ice off Lake Wallenpaupack in Pennsylvania just before Easter in 1986. I stepped onto the dry ground ice and rode it as it gently pushed ashore, piled up, and broke into weak shards and ice straws. The ice pushed a large adjacent boulder through the sand and mud, creating an eight-foot-wide, three-foot-deep trench. I could easily reach into that bad ice and smash it in my hand, but the immense power exerted by a light breeze on the surface of a couple of square kilometers of ice was unstoppable and incredible to witness.

But wait, what about the stakes? Two rocks inside a circle of stakes, how does the ice move one and not the other? How does it move past the stakes at all? Why does it not knock the stakes over? I could sort of picture two rocks, both frozen in ice, the ice breaks and one just happens to be carried off with the floating sheet, the other one is left behind, or that ice stays where it is. But the only sheet of ice that could fit out of the ring of stakes would be too small to carry a rock with it. If it had enough force to carry a rock, it would have enough to knock over a lightly driven stake. If it couldn't, it seems like the stakes would hold the ice stationary. And if the ice was driven past and through the stakes, it would break the ice up and you would no longer have sheets of ice. If the ice piled up instead, then why would it only move one rock and not the other?
So I guess everything can be answered by physics except the how of our universe's existence. When that answer comes I can finally move on. Haha

Hello Physics Girl from Wales. I've just found your channel and about to explore the great subjects that you cover. Many congratulations on some excellent content. On the subject of ice sheets and wind moving things i have actually seen this happening.

Please search for Caerphilly Castle and you'll see that it has a moat. The moat freezes with layers of thin ice regularly. Mainly because it is where the coldest air accumulates at the lowest point in a geographical basin and freezing flowing air down from the Welsh valleys etc. When younger it was customary to find shopping trolleys thrown into the moat. Over time the trolleys would migrate across the moat because the mass of the ice could simply drag them.
When walking home from school we might see them in a different place each day.

The video never gets at what seems to me to be a key question, which is how can such thin ice (1/8" thick I believe they said) move such a heavy rock?  If you put a rock of a 6" diameter  and say 3" thick on top of a 1/8" thick piece of ice, the ice will break.  Is the key point that all the movement occurs parallel to the ground, and thus along the length of the ice, in which dimension it is much stronger?  But surely there would be a little twisting (particularly to lift the rock) that would break the ice.  Or is the key point that many of these thin sheets of ice get piled on top of one another by the wind, and perhaps stick to one another, forming a much thicker much stronger sheet of ice? How I perceive it, the rock is lodged in ice and ice floats on water. The lodged rock now 'weighs' slightly less due to buoyancy effect, eventhough it is still touching the ground. (Think floating lifebuoy ring stopping a person from sinking) Fine dust mixed with water acts like lubricated rollers underneath the rock. (Easier to roll or slide over wet compact sand than dry loose sand) Hence, overall coefficient of friction is greatly reduced.
A combination of the water current pushing on the rock from below and the shifting ice plates pushing the rock from above, provides enough lateral force to overcome the now reduced frictional forces. End result, the rock moves.

I recently was made aware of your Channel by watching Dereks Veretasium channel and then your colab. The topic of the colab was sunscreen and it was from 2018. A very recent study has found some issues with some sunscreens.

Nothing to do with UV, but their ingredients. Not sure if it is worth looking into for you or it fits your channel at all, but since you have a video about sunscreens already I thought you might want to know.

"A study by the CNRS, France's national scientific research centre, and Sorbonne University has just demonstrated that octocrylene, an ingredient used in sunscreen creams and day creams to protect skin from the sun, degrades over time and then generates benzophenone."

"Benzophenone is persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic (PBT). These chemicals are linked to cancer, endocrine disruption, and organ system toxicity"

Most sunscreens don't have a traditional "best before" but they have an open jar with a number printed on them which indicates how fast you should use them after you opened them. Actually I don't believe the thin ice on top can move the rocks all together, because someone else I watched saw them move without no water visable in the lake bed, even though a huge panel of ice can move them just a little bit thin ice would most likely break up when it encountered resistence.  It is actually what happens after a rare rain or snow event in Death Valley, the snow melts during the day and seeps under the the rock on oneside and freezes, the snow on the top of the boulder melts and freezes attaching the whole rock to the froozen sediment at the bottom of the lake bed and than the wind blows a certain direction and the rocks skate around on the frozen soil as the ice is under the top layer of soil.  Its just a light breeze that makes them move too because of the rocks surface being covered in ice and the soil underneath being covered in ice it reduces the friction between the rocks and the ground causing them to move.

I needed to know the resistance of am unknown wirewound resistor, so in the morning after making my favorite coffee on my kuerig I decided to use my lab meter vs my handheld. on the lab meter is uses a 4 wire measurement where as my hand held does not. So I went to my lab and thats where I say my assistant, we walked to the areas where the lab gear is on the shelf, we turned it on and let it warm up. let me tell you about warming up, you can use this cool product xyz as a hand warmer and great for camping, go buy one to help me out. Let me tell you why this is so amazing, using the 4 wire meter we can get very accurate measurements by eliminated the voltage drop across the leads. but here is the thing, the longer the leads increase the drop, but also did you know the more current the resistor draws the even bigger the voltage drop. --- do you see my point? I had to watch a lot of fluff just to get the the meat of this video, sure I dont have to watch it through I had to skip forward, skip back, jump around. too much fluff. ok, I know a lot of people going to write negative comments to my negative comment, but at least mine has a point

Don't believe the "it can't be ice on a salt pond" argument!  Ages and ages ago, I worked with a physicist studying salt-stabilized solar ponds as solar collectors.  Under the right conditions, the density gradient caused by a salinity gradient, will stabilize a salt pond against vertical mixing.  Drop a layer of snow on top of that, and you'll have a thin film of fresh water that internally convects, sitting atop the stable salt gradient.  The convecting layer has a sharp lower boundary, and salt only passes through it by diffusion, so it can take quite a long time for that layer to acquire enough salt to significantly depress its freezing temperature.

Just before Easter in 1986, I watched a light breeze push the winter ice off Lake Wallenpaupack in Pennsylvania.  I walked on to the ice that had reached dry ground and rode it as it slowly pushed ashore, piled up and broke into flimsy shards and ice straws.  The ice pushed a huge nearby boulder through the sand and mud, leaving a trench about eight feet wide and three feet deep.  I could reach into that rotten ice and crush it so easily in my hand, but the massive force exerted by a light breeze on the surface of a couple of square miles of ice was absolutely unstoppable and awesome to see.

The water pushes them closer and closer until they hit the wave breaker boulders and then it completely destroys the summer shoreline. Its pretty crazy to watch and listen to. Also, every year someone that comes down from the city, who has never seen something like this before, climbs the ice mounds, falls through, and gets trapped under 6-8ft of solid ice in 10ft deep water. I found it interesting that everyone was surprised by the very minor ice depth. I recall sailing on keelboats and we learned pretty early on that new sailors and the untrained ones tend to wait to long to reef their sails so as to reduce the surface area because you can really overpower once you get some storm winds. The saying was "When was it time to reef the sails? 20 minutes ago."

There is enough power in a 28' keelboat's main sail to get the heavy thousand(s) of pounds keel up and out of the water if you don't reef, free the sail to depower, or come upwind to be directly head into the wind (and in a storm wind, you might not be able to hold that nose in position without an engine because the winds hitting your hull will probably have you going sideways momentarily if the pressure is a bit more on one side than the other side.

I've actually been in a 24' keelboat where we got the rudder out of the water (easier than the keel.... usually if you get the bottom parts of the keel showing, you're going over (capsizing)). On the non-racing sailboats, the natural behaviour is weather helm when your rudder comes up out of the water... your ship naturally turns upwind, somewhat depowers the sail or you let it go (though that isn't a great idea as it is hazardous and not good for the sail, but in emergencies, you sometimes need an effect right now, not a better one later). When power comes off the sail, the boat comes more upright and you get the rudder back in the water and you have steering once again.

In some of the racing keelboats (I don't mention catamarans because they are a bit different), the effect that will occur if you get the vessel too far over is NOT a turn into the wind and depowering... as it is lee helm instead of weather helm (turning away from the wind versus turning upwind). It's why some of the racing boats need to be handled with very competent sailors.

https://sailing-blog.nauticed.org/weather-helm-vs-lee-helm-%E2%80%93-what-is-it-how-to-use-it/

There are entire books on sail shapes and advantages and disadvantages and the most expensive racing ships have hulls designed and matched to the sail plan for the ship and a lot of math and fluid dynamics probably apply.

Anyway, a sufficiently sturdy but not too thick ice sheet could make a great sail and with a bit of water underneath, that would help too as the sail of ice would move a bit faster over ice than if it was directly scraping all the way into the bottom sand. And along go the stones.

I worked in R&D on a new roofing membrane that would move slowly West in hot climates after about two years in place. After 5 years it would crawl about one foot up the West parapet wall, and shrink about one foot away from the East parapet wall.  Turns out it  was a combination of multiple factors.  Hot days. parapet walls over 2 feet high, viscoelastic adhesive membrane, and long sections (60 feet) of roofing membrane oriented East-West. So.... see if you can figure it out. Hint: thermal expansion AND contraction over long distances with different temperature gradients through out the day, and a temperature sensitive thermoplastic adhesive spelled doom for that product....LOL

As a Commercial Diver, I can confirm that it is a regular occurance that a thin layer of fresh water will form on top of salt water. Fresh water freezes at a higher temp than salt water does, due to salt water having higher density than fresh water. My evidence is base on practical experiance over decades diving in Scottish and Norwegian sea lochs on fish farms. Once a salt water inlet has a fresh water layer, and freezes, forming an ice covering, then further snow or rain covers, that then forms and and reinforces the ice covering.

Amazing story, but I do see the power of ice sheets. We had a rare occurrence on Lake Winnipeg, Manitoba , Canada when everything happened just right and formed huge piles of snowy -looking ice on the west shore. The mechanism seemed to be a steady wind pushing large sheets of ice which would climb atop the shore most piece and be pushed by the large sheet until it would break off and repeat over and over reaching a depth of 10 meters or 30 feet. The effect is awesome and the piles would actually be pushed further shore-ward by the large sheet of ice behind it. Like I said, conditions have to be in perfect concert with the ice the wind and the temperatures. I only recall seeing this once in my lifetime. Enjoyed the video immensely, cheers!

LOL I saw a video about this years ago and instantly thought about Curling. Than a year or 2 later it was figured out and it was based on the theory of Curling: like a glass pushed across a table, a curling stone leans forward slightly. The extra pressure at the front of the stone partially melts the ice at the leading edge, creating a thin film of water that reduces the friction at the front of stone compared with the back. The conditions are like a natural curling rink in that desert at night.

Besides the obvious interesting factor of this experiment and research, I wonder the larger scale engineering and science lessons this could teach and innovate with. While oceans maintain exceptionally high surface tension, and take large amounts of wind and force to cause surges, it seems that with the same or less force, Ice sheets upon shallow lakes or bodies of water can maintain an increasingly higher amount of movement and consistent directional velocity, to the point where they have actively change their surroundings in significant ways. I wonder if this could revolutionize methods of energy or engineering via manipulating nature in such a way to "capitalize" on high intensity weather or natural events, almost like Natural disaster farming. Imagine huge scale shallow lakes across the north-east and west of the United States and Canada, built in positions that create extremely high wind valleys, but also can maintain quick freezes and melting, to where sheet ice can be formed, and then formulating a method, such as objects, or possibly introduction of other minerals to increase the possibility of these conditions, and adding some method of generating power from such. If you could place the top end of large water wheels where they intersect the pools without heavily interfering with the current, you could effectively run hundreds of water wheels with varying efficiency and generate power that could be significantly greater than some other methods.
Of course, I'm not a scientist of the field, and this could all just be babbling, but such an idea is fascinating to me.

To be VERY clear, the Racetrack Valley is NOT Death Valley. It's within the Death Valley National Park. Brent over on Ghost Town Living used to say Cerro Gordo was next to Death Valley until I and others urged him to change his nomenclature... and to his credit, he did! As you discovered in getting there from Stonepipe, it's quite a ways from Death Valley, so tourists beware of thinking that a visit to Death Valley proper will include a visit to Racetrack Playa. It will not. I am a Californian and avid 4WD enthusiast in that part of our wonderful State and even I have only ventured there once. And only from the "long" easy way. Good luck getting there via Lippencott. I urge folks unfamiliar with the geography of the area to go, like you did, via the Scotty's Castle way through Grapevine and past Ubehebe Crater (which, by the way, is awesome and deserves it's own frightening video).

The school system used to teach a class called Logic, over 100 years ago, but when the dummies took over the school system, they removed this class. The solution to this mystery was very simple, if you used Logic, which breaks things down to the the basic logical cause and effect consequences. 1) The trails had to be made, while the lake bed was wet, because of how they erased the cracked lake bed etc 2) The lake bed did get very wet on occasion because of the cracking effect left behind. 3) The only natural forces that can move heavy rocks are fast moving water or ice. This is not a narrow river bed, so fast moving water is out of the question. This in not a glacier, so that is out of the question, plus a glacier would not leave behind this type of evidence. So a sheet of ice is the only option. 4) The water in this lake bed never gets deep enough to form rolling waves, so there would not be enough force to break up or to move thick ice. 5) The only option left is a thin sheet of ice, which can be moved by wind, as it partially covers the water surface. 6) As thin ice moves, it can pile up as it meets resistence such as a rock. 7) As the rock is moved in a wet, flat, silt filled lake bed, it will carve a path, especially so, if it is moved very slowly and is 50 to 200 lbs. 8) Anyone who has lived next to a lake, on the receiving side of the wind, for a long time, has seen the ice move against the shore line, pushing over anything in it's way. You see this more often in rivers.

30 Years ago while attending a Geology Course at Palomar College in San Diego County we visited the "Racetrack" in Death Valley a couple of times over the years, at that time our Professor stated to us that it was most likely a combination of ICE and WIND which moved those rocks around the "Racetrack".  Previously researchers had tried to use the power of airplane propellers to unsuccessfully move the rocks, but alas ICE was not present at the time!  So decades later if appears that our beloved Professor was 100% CORRECT, it was the WIND and a thin layer of ICE that allowed the rocks to be moved!  Hope he was able to see this video!

Ice, water wind are incredibly powerful. Anyone who has seen ice break ups knows. It doesn't take hurricane force winds. It that slow gentle push (force) exerted on a massive surface area that keeps it from breaking up so tremendous forces are exerted on snag points.
It's pneumatics over hydraulics to make mechanical advantage.
Some lakes and ponds around here are very susceptible to shoreline damage from a very similar process. If conditions are right.
Thaw occurs leaving a flotilla of thinner ice not attached to shore. Then a steady gentle constant breeze or wind will push it on shore. It's thin enough to ride up and over itself. Knock down trees move rocks and earth.

Where once people used to come to this place to feel their minds wander to inexplicable, fanciful places of awe, now the mystery is dead..... Kind of like how a fantasy can live on until you experience it.... the fantasy then dies and it no longer holds a place in your mind. Sometimes a thing looses its appeal when you break it down into its constituent elements. An imagination-capturing phenomenon has been reduced to nothing more than wind, ice, and rocks. I can already hear the sounds of economists & land developers wringing their hands in anticipation.

One thing to remember along with this is that the night doesn't have to be subfreezing for ice to form.  The sky is usually clear above the playa, so you get large amounts of night-sky radiation which chills things down farther than ambient air temp.  The Persians used to make ice in the desert this way, in narrow walled channels open at the top.  This is also what causes a frosty car roof on a calm night that's still above freezing.  So more of the "winter" nights could easily support ice formation if there's water present in the first place.

In 2010, I worked as a contractor at Grand Forks AFB ND and while flying one day I noticed HUGE gouges in the earth that stretcher for mile and mile.   The explanation that was offered was that of course during the ICE AGE a large portion of North America had been covered by a huge Glacier.  Either during the Southward march of the Ice (this seems most likely) or alternatively the Northward retraction of the glacier, had trapped huge amounts of rock material in the ice and drug the collection along with its movement gouging these enormous trenches in the earth.    Could this be a similar phenomena to the Moving rocks in death valley but on an Much Much Larger scale?   You can see these gouge marks clearly for yourself on Google earth by looking 4 miles west of Grand Forks AFB at these coordinates :    47° 57'13.95"N    97° 28'31.24"W   Tell me what you think? That said, I wonder if a similar phenomenon could be involved with the Nazca Lines. Perhaps during pre-human habitation -- say an ice age or warming event -- wind and water conditions at that location were conducive to similar effect. Humans might have discovered that area MUCH+++ later, and the stones that scribed these lines might have been removed by them and perhaps tooled into various religious forms. Eventually rituals developed in the indigenous culture to travel the paths lining them with rocks creating another layer of intrigue to that mystery. 😁 I'm stoked to hear about any follow-up to this theory.

Living in the land of ice near the northern part of the Great Lakes we witness a number of unique ice events. Including wind driving the spring ice amazing distances with perceptible speed along with great force. Separately a Friend of ours has a rock quarry that upon occasion seems to let some large rocks travel as much as a hundred yards without any apparent provocation. Always in the cold season and a bit slower than walking speed. These rocks, sometimes the size of a VW, are usually relatively flat bottomed and move while the ground is frozen with no visible pitch to the  ground. Light rains turn the old naturally slimey top surface of theclay lake bed very slippery, and strong winds push all the rocks along in the same direction. The rock leaves a trail in the soft clay surface. Below the top surface is a denser or harder part that does not become mud when rained upon, so the rocks do not sink or dig into t e ground.

Anybody who has stepped into a shower that has been uncleaned for a while is familiar with how slippery it can get from the same effect. The slimey resuidue once weted again becomes slippery as heck, but the bathtub plastic or porcelin beneath remains hard. When it's dry, it's not slippery, but as soon as you turn on the shower, boom, it's slippery. The solution is to use yoru foot or a scrub brush to scrub off all the slimey film that can't be seen.

In 1975 I was in a huge flat parking lot, over a mile long, surrounded by flat fields and factory buildings. Where I was standing it was dry, but I could see an intense downpour on another part of the property. It was raining so hard you could not see into the storm. The water spread out and when it got to me it was enough to push concrete parking stops out of place. An MG Midget was pushed into a larger car next to it. I read about the moving stones in the 80’s, in Scientific American I think, and wrote to them, describing the rain in that parking lot, suggesting that a desert downpour in a much bigger flat plane might have been pushing the stones on muddy, slippery ground. My letter was neither published nor answered.

And also on other documentaries about brinicles and the salt cycle on Earth, that there are rivers of super-salinated water coming from the antarctic, and possibly the Arctic Ice as it melts, because the fresh water goes up and the super salinated water sinks, so that there is even vast underwater waterfalls of super-salinated water...

If rain froze fast enough on a cold night as it fell, it could create a sheet of ice that other ice and snow could form on top of before it ever saturated into the salty ground...

Regarding the unique geology in Death Valley it is what is known as a graben a type of feature found in extensional terrain. In this case its a rift feature where the Pacific has been spreading apart the sierra microplate from the Baja peninsula/western California and so like the Salton sea you have low lying volcanically active thin crust. Many if not most of these Grabens will fail to form much if anything but a select few will grow into new ocean basins.  These low lying terrains otherwise though will generally get filled in by sediment over millions of years.

My brother and I visited this playa in 1987. we didn't plan to solve anything but wanted to see the rocks and their tracks. We checked out a lot of them, marveling at each one. and then, without even trying, it dawned on us how the rocks moved.
We visited the playa in the summer, but we brought a USGS map with us, which noted the elevation of the valley was something like 4,000 feet. Being California natives, we knew that the snow in the mountains often reached down to less than 3,000 feet, and stayed there for weeks at a time. So we knew about the night freezes, and the temporary lakes, and the way the wind could move so many rocks in the same patterns at the same time. It took us less than an hour to figure out all that is presented in this video. The only thing we didn't consider is that the wind also drove the water higher up on the shallow gradient of the dry lake bed, only to have it flow back down after the wind stopped. That little bit of information is the nicest part of this video.
We figured that many people must have figured this our before we did, and then left the answer for other people, like my brother and me, to discover for ourselves. So, as interesting as this video has been, the discovery is only one of quite likely thousands. Still, it's a great video, and not only checks what my brother and I figured out, but also elaborates on in a new and interesting way. Thanks for showing this!

My father, Allen Bassett a geology prof at SD State in the 1960's, told us (and many others) this story. He was called by an acquaintance of his, John S Shelton, author of the book "Geology Illustrated". John was a pilot and this book was a compendium of aerial photos showing geologic features. John called and asked my father if he wanted to go out to the Racetrack Playa to test a theory about the moving rocks. So, they flew out and landed on the playa while it was still wet but not under water. They taxied up to a rock with the plane facing away from it so that the backwash from the prop would push a strong wind onto the rock to see if it would move. They chocked the wheels, or tied down the plane, I don't remember the details, and revved up the engine to give a pretty strong windy push to the rock. The rocks did not move either the small or large ones. I'm not sure if the ice theory had been thought of yet by this time, but to them it only added to the mystery of the Racetrack playa.

Hydraulic pressure is one of the greatest sources of power! However, to move stone with ice is not an unthinkable possibility. Rock and stone is very porous and absorbs water like a sponge. So while sitting in water it becomes full of water. When the temperature drops and freezes the water, the water in the stone freezes also. Ice in water becomes buoyant which makes it weigh less. Therefore when the wind blows and moves the ice it's clear to see that the frozen rocks that weigh much less than normal can also be moved much easier than not frozen.

I liked your vid, but I think your audience deserves a little more detail and less hype about where Racetrack Valley is. While it is in the newly expanded Death Valley National Park, It is not in Death Valley proper; in fact, it is way to the west, just east of Saline Valley. There are many playas and mountain ranges between it and Death Valley. Racetrack Valley is not the "hottest place on earth", the elevation is 3,700', and it's usually a reasonable mid to high 90's in the summer months. And obviously, it can be pretty cold in the winter.
Living relatively nearby I visit the place every year or so, coming in by the Hunter Mountain road or the Lippencott Grade. I almost never take the "tourist road" from Death Valley, though that is an interesting way too.

When I started shooting photos at Racetrack in the early 2000s, there were almost no footprints or signs of people disturbing the playa when it was wet. Since the huge social media explosion, and all of the attention brought by the explanation, it's now almost impossible to find rocks without footprints around them. Please - if you want to visit the playa, don't walk on the surface if it's at all soft - your footprints will ruin it for everyone else that comes after you for decades. Kudos to them for solving the mystery, but every time I see something else published about this place, I know it means it will never be the same again...

The movement of the rocks occurs when large, thin sheets of ice floating on an ephemeral winter pond break up in the sun. Frozen during cold winter nights, these thin, floating ice panels are driven by wind and shove rocks at speeds up to 5 meters per minute. Source: wikipedia

Something similar occurs all over fields in New England. This is the reason for all the low rock walls that litter old farmland there. Farmers had to get them out of the way, off the fields, because otherwise they would move! I read an old pamphlet from the late 1800s where the author calculated there was more stones built into New England walls than in all the Egyptian Pyramids. Not just to mark boundaries, but because otherwise the rocks moved along the fields in winter, especially when temperatures hovered just around the freezing point. The big difference is that no New Englander ever thought to publish such findings in a scientific paper. Seen as a big mystery to be solved by 21st century academics in the California desert, just seemed too ordinary to make a fuss about in ye olde New England.Because otherwise the rocks moved along the fields in winter.

Great stuff.  I immediately thought of clay on a potters wheel.  The clay, in this case the sedimentary layer, can be almost impermeable over time through the sun baking it over long periods of time during those hot summers.  But, add a bit of water to it, and as it has not been fired in a kiln at temps to tun it into ceramic, the boundary layer becomes very slick.  Thus, a thin layer of ice, coupled with wind can form a kind of seiche event that will move these rocks along.

That jives with what I said years ago, that the mechanism behind the mysterious moving rocks would be something they tested, but not thoroughly, and it would have something to do with ice. Looking at the patterns the tracks made on the surface, and how they seemed to match each other in a single event of rock motion, the only thing that could make all of the ones that moved match each other's movements would have to be something that binds them into one piece. What is really weird is the thinness of that substance, which is ice. I knew it had to be ice, but not just 1/8 of an inch thick! But when I think about it now, I see that the rocks simply acted as sails that the wind acted against to move the ice sheet itself. The ice is not moving the rocks! Rather the rocks are moving the ice sheet, by acting as sails. Makes sense, and shows how little we really know about the physics of the Universe.

While in college near San Luis Obispo (and taking classes in geology), I went on a 3 day geological field trip to Death Valley.  What a fascinating place!!  And yes, we all put forth hypothesis about racetrack & the rocks...all incorrect however. And this is what I love about science & scientists. They see the seemingly unexplainable...and get to work solving the mystery. And although I pursued a career in medicine, rather than geology....the geological field trips I took, are some of my fondest memories. (PS...we students and our professors were lucky enough to attend a one-woman show at an old movie theater named the Amagossa Opera House. The place had been featured in National Geographic, as a ballet/modern dancer by the name of Martha Beckett had painted the interior to resemble a 16th Century Spanish Court. Story was, that she danced professionally, until her doctors recommend she move to the desert for health reasons. Her and her husband Tom purchssed the run down theater and U-shaped motel and she painted the interior so that she would have an audience, while she danced. When we saw her "perform"....she must have been in her 70's or more, and danced ballet...doing multiple acts and costume changes that evening. Oh...and when we pulled up to the theater in our big school vans, we were greeted by none other than her husband Tom....in a full Tuxedo...in the middle of this desert landscape....truly a bizarre sight to behold!!).

Yea the Spain story sounds very convincing at a glance but we also must remember that salt dissolving in water COSTS a lot of energy, it is an endothermic reaction. So realistically while the freezing point indeed does go down, the water will also take a significant local temperature dip allowing the first crystals to form and from there you're pretty much done for in preventing the sheet to form. This is why you should never just throw salt at your front porch to prevent ice formation, always mix it with a few handsful of sand to soak up the water and stop that crystal formation.

Some of those grooves became the "Finger Lakes" in New York state.

I figured something out.

The mass of the rocks wasn't the amazing factor. It was the super slippery layer of water between the sheet of ice and the sand that enabled the entire thing to move as a singular object. The wind was able to move the ice because of how wide and thin it was.

Yes, the ice crumbled. But in parts where they moved as one, it caught all of the wind's force spread across its total surface area and slid. And rocks pinning it down didn't stand a chance.

Once the ice starts to lock on a rock additional freezing expands the sheet, slightly lifting some weight of the rock. Additional water will lift a bit more so the weight of the rock is not fully dragging the ground (pond bottom).
Wet dirt is mud, mud is slippery.

So temporary lift and lube, combined with wind drag on flat ice (sail), and current of water, is just enough to scoot these rocks along.

But who wants to go outside on a yukky day?

Very thorough analysis, but what nags at me is the one experiment inside the stakes, wherein the one rock moved and the other didn't. I didn't see any leaning of the stakes in the direction of travel of the stone. Wouldn't the stakes breaking up the ice sheet have exponentially reduced the amount of force on the stone? Would just the unbroken mass of ice pushing directly against the stone have been strong enough, at...what? 1/8 of an inch thick, he said? Would that have been enough to move that mass?

He said that the stones that move are dolomite? Dolomite is an anhydrous calcium magnesium carbonate that can become slightly electrically conductive by ion-hopping. How much of a charge is all that water picking up on its way down into that bed, I wonder? There wouldn't be much in the way of saturation, so there would be an electric double-layer between the water and the soil, which conceivably carry a very large amount of charge down from the slopes to the lake bed.

I wonder if that charge, flowing through the water and acting specifically on dolomite, or even other silicate rocks, be enough to electromagnetically drag the stones with the charge flow, at the low end/collector of the lake bed. Not all by itself, of course, but to act in concert with the flow of current-carrying molecules around it (the water and ice).

Too often we look for one 'magic bullet' to explain observable phenomena, when it's actually many physical forces operating in conjunction. Having orked in the field of Electronics for so long, I confess to being rather prejudiced towards explaining things in electrodynamic terms, and seeing things as plasmas. Heh, not sorry! ;)

1:53 - NO FREAKING JOKE! Short-story-time: I lived the cautionary tale for that warning, back about 20 years ago, changing a flat in the dirt road "parking lot" at the sailing stones! An inch-long stone shaped like a T-rex tooth punctured right thru the fattest tread blocks on my fresh off-road tires on my pickup. Aaaand my spare that I hadn't checked in years was SUPER low on air (but at least holding).

As dusk was falling and still 26 miles down washboard road from the nearest pavement, a Jeep was going the other way. I suspected a Jeep going the "wrong way" at dusk in Death Valley was probably better prepared than I was, and they seemed surprised when I asked if they had an air compressor, but they did! Long day, no casualties.

As I learned later, aside from my inadequate spare-tire-&-compressor prep, it's recommended to drop about 10 lbs. below "street" air pressure when venturing off-road, as it helps with terrain compliance, ride comfort, and puncture-resistance. But don't trust this random internet lunatic on that: talk to a proper off-road guide.

Happy physicsing!! <3

I've made many trips to Death Valley over the years, and my favorite place is definitely the Racetrack Playa.  It's fantastic to see the "mystery of the rocks" solved in this video.  I always felt that it had something to do with the playa becoming wet and slippery, but "ice" never occurred to me.  I will also say, to anyone who'd like to make the trip, yes, it's long way, and lots of driving, but it's well worth the effort and somewhat life changing.  There's an energy that stays with you, when you see the rocks with their long tracks and also see the Grandstand in the distance.  One tip, which I learned to help prevent getting your tires punctured on the gravel roads in and around the area, is to take out about 15-20% of the air in your tires.  This will soften the tires, and will allow them to flex a bit more when driving over jagged rocks.  This flexing, will prevent the rock from puncturing the tire tread. And once back to Stove Pipe or Furnace Creek, you can refill the tires with air, or carry cans of air, which are easily bought at a car parts store.  Works great, and I have never had a flat!

comment_text: que kk

While I respect your quality content, it’s become more and more common for YouTubers to put the answer to their videos question at the start.

If your video isn’t engaging enough to watch without the lure of an answer at the end it’s probably not worth watching.

At 6:13 in the video, several papers are shown. John Reid, the first author of Sliding Rocks of Death Valley: What makes them move? was my advisor at the time (1995); the other authors were fellow students. I was not part of the research team, but as a student at a collaboratively oriented college , I did participate in discussions and making the calculations presented in the manuscript. To my knowledge, it was the first time large scale detailed measurements were made and the required wind shear forces were calculated and resolved with the mechanism of wind shear on a large ice sheets and reduced friction of the rocks on wet mud , and the conclusions were fundamentally correct. Notable in that publication is mapping that demonstrates that rocks moved in groups that would divide into subgroups, an observation that necessitates either ice sheets or divine intervention to accomplish! The contribution of the research by the Richard and James Norris is to irrefutably demonstrate the findings of that research with technology not readily available 25 years ago. It is important to give all credit where credit is due. The contribution of the Norris' work is wonderful, and it satisfying to see the phenomenon that we understood 25 years ago so elegantly proven. I think it would be more accurate although perhaps less sensational to say that they provided the unequivocal proof of research that solved the mystery in 1995. Congratulations to all!

Interesting how obvious it becomes once you consider the evidence.

1. Only rocks above a certain height move
2. Rocks shorter than that height do not move
3. They all move in precisely the same direction and all at once
4. There is a limited area of rocks that move, and the ones outside that region don't move

This all suggests that it must be something that connects the rocks together, but only above a certain height, and needs to move simultaneously, a sheet of ice acting like a sail is the only answer that makes sense with the evidence above.

The interesting thing is that its not the mass of ice acting on the rocks, but the thin ice's non-compressibility acting on a plane, and the force of the wind pushing on that plane. Its like pushing a big rock with a thin rigid stick, you can push the rock as long as the stick is kept perfectly straight so it does not buckle and break. That's my theory, and it would be interesting to know whether rocks closer to the trailing edge of the ice sheet don't move as much, if at all - those rocks will need to be more pulled rather than pushed by the ice (and water/ice has little tensile strength).

Some fishermen in Alaska could have figured that out. Some times of the year a person may anchor their boat in in a little bay inside a bigger bay, and then in the morning find oneself trapped in sheet ice. The freshwater floats on top of salt water and forms that layer of sheet ice. When the tide starts to go out the boat maybe in jeopardy as the ice takes the boat along for the ride and drags the anchor along the bottom. Two problems may occur. The anchor hangs up and the ice continues to push the boat until it rolls over, or the sheet ice can literally cut through the hull of the boat, especially a wooden boat, and damage the boat.
One captain I worked for had to spend all night running his boat in a circle to keep the area clear of sheet ice so he didn't get pushed out of the little ba and into the big bay and rolled over by the ice.

Interesting how the biases we 'learn' as youngsters persist for years, precluding curiosity about phenomena we directly experience.  For example, the notion that salty water won't freeze.  While that is true as has been demonstrated in the lab, there are contingencies in nature where the impossible actually does happen.  When rain falls on salty lakes, it can form a thin layer of fresh water that gets super cooled and forms ice.  I have seen this effect in a salt water basin near Sooke, BC.  I was astonished to see ice on seawater, and realized that there was a small stream trickling rainwater onto the still waters of the basin.  The temperature was relatively mild, within a few degrees of 0C.

It makes a lot of sense really.  The rock gets trapped in a sheet of ice that floats on the water.  If the sheet of ice is big enough, it does not take much force (per square inch) exerted on the ice to lift the rock up just a touch so it can be moved.  A bit of wind to create a slight lifting force (like a wave) that will move the sheet of ice up and over.  I suspect that this only happens once at least part of the lake ice has broken to allow the wind to act on the water.

This story rocks

Sailors often leave boat moorings in the water to avoid the hassle of removing them with their anchors & chains, for the winter and replacing them in the spring.
In a tidal zone, like Quincy Bay (Boston Harbor), where the tide can rise by 9-12 feet as water and ice ebb and flow twice a day.
Leaving them attached to their floats isn't a great idea -- easier for the ice to hold.
So sailors typically replace the float with a long narrow winterstick that juts out of the water low tide and is hard for the ice to grab on to.
But, the "ground tackle" can still be carried away by the ice.
Years ago, a young man who lived along the shore made a pretty good sum, dragging the bottom to find long lost ground tackle.
Which was were my 200# mushroom and 10' of Navy chain came from for my boat 40 years ago.
The best thing to do there was to remove the anchor and chain and store it nearby, which is one of many advantages of belonging to a yacht club.
People helping each other do with a common interest.

I was a park ranger at Death Valley for five years, stationed at Stovepipe Wells. I was there when it was announced that the mystery of the Racetrack was solved. Upon hearing the news, I remember simultaneously having an "aha!" moment as well as feeling a bit of disappointment. One of my favorite aspects of the mystery was that even in the second decade of the twenty-first century, there were still unexplained phenomena right here on planet earth. I rather enjoyed telling visitors "I don't know" whenever they asked me about the Racetrack. Park Rangers rarely get to say that phrase! 😁 I used to patrol out to the Racetrack regularly, and it was always a sublime experience to walk out among the moving rocks and imagine how they moved. This video brought back many great memories. Thanks Diana for making this!

Not to brag but as a geologist this felt very obvious. Glad it's been confirmed, but before the video even properly started, my first suspicion was ice. Deserts are known to get below freezing at night because there's often very little cloud cover, and clouds are what trap heat in. No clouds, no heat trapped, heat radiates away from earth and the temperature falls drastically. As for why it's thin sheet ice and not thick ice, my guess is that it's easier for ice forming in high wind if it forms in thin layers. One layer forms, is moved while another forms, and they separate like that.

I understand that the rocks also move when the playa is dry. Please consider that the surface of the playa is bentonite (a very active soil that expanses when wet and shrinks when dry). A Smithsonian article several years addressed this matter. I communicated with the author and shared my experience with patio slabs-on-grade moving away from houses when exposed to concentrated moisture on the house side and drying on the opposite side. The author and I agree that the rocks are being pushed along because the soil beneath the surface is wet due to periodic rain and flooding of the surface. The sun dries the surface, but the subgrade remains moist relative to the surface. The rocks protect the surface from drying and allow the drier soil beneath the rock to draw moisture from below. When the sun strikes one side of the rock, the soil on that side of the rock dries and shrinks. The soil on the shaded side of the rock remains moist and swollen. This differential in moisture and corresponding expansion of the soil beneath the rock, pushes the rock toward the dry side of the rock. Note that these soils can exert huge pressures as they expand... in the range of 20,000 pounds per square foot. To test this explanation, one could select two of the moving rocks and shade one to see if that rock remains in place while the other rock moves. I look forward to the next episode of your investigation.

This explanation was put forward more or less the same back in the 80s'. Since i saw it in one episode of Arthur C Clarkes Mysterious World, the Cabinet of Curiosities episode, they had a segment dealing with Death Valleys moving stones and a geologist by the name of Dwight Carrey was studying the phenomena he came up with the idea that in the right moments when its windy and wet enough (usually when no one is around, or at least back then), you get just the right conditions to push the rocks along the slick surface... their only difference was they didnt mention the ice factor, and factored in extremely rare storms that occurred at night.

OK I'm paused at 5:03 and I have a hypothesis:
The wind blows dust under the rocks, forming a lil dirt pile on the windward side of the rocks. On the rare occasion there is some moisture in the air, the dirt absorbs some and expands. This a) pushes the rock a tiny bit and b) compresses the ground below it slightly. Once the dirt dries out again it is either blown into the gap left as it shrinks, or is blown away, ready for the wind to start a new pile.

A story, the mysterious ghostly soda can which moves on its own. A friend of mine was convinced that the apartment in which he stayed at was haunted. During the summer months, soda cans would glide across the coffie table and stop at the edge. He would place the can in the center portion of the table and several minutes later it would begin to glide across the table and then stop right at the edge. He called me up and seemed very concerned about this mystery can. I arrived and as I sat down on the sofa near the table, the can began its trip to the edge. I replaced the can back in its original position and after a couple of minutes it made the trip once again. What I noticed was, the can was nearly empty, sun was shining on the table, condensation had built up on the outside of the can and left a bit of water where the can sat originally. The solution... the sun would warm up the can, the water ring created a seal between the can and table, the dome on the bottom of the can had enough volume to allow the air to expand from the heat transfered from the sun soaked can. As the air expanded it lifted the can just enough to be nearly weightless, the water ring behaved like the apron on a hoovercraft and also provided lubrication. When someone would sit on the sofa near the table it would cause the table to go out of level just enough to get the can to start moving. The surface tension of the water made it adhere to the cans surface and the table top was made of some type of "Formica" which gave it a hydrophobic condition. Thus the water tended to remain with the can, once it reached the edge of the table, the seal would break and the air pressure would drop to ambient thus stopping the can. Once I explained what was going on, he felt a bit of sadness now knowing the place wasnt haunted ( which confused me, for I wouldnt be happy about living in a haunted apartment). So, no ghosts, only a bit of warm air and some water on a smooth surface and a bit of tilt.......

Watching a small freshwater stream flow into the ocean is rather neat cause about 1 to 3 inches below the surface you can see the saltwater/freshwater interface. Normally best seen in good light, but with some shadows, no waves at all, and a rising tide.

Moving very heavy rocks could perhaps happen if somewhat thick ice formed at lower water depths, then additional water was added to the basin. Just enough to float the ice sheet. Ice, like boats, can carry very heavy loads through buoyancy.

So my theory on the Spain issue is that salt water is much more dense than fresh water even more so in very saline salt lakes.  So, after a rain there can be a layer of fresh water over the salt which can freeze and act like the salt sheets in death valley.  I know this as when you are diving or snorkeling in calm water after a rain you can actually see the line where the layer of fresh water is blending into the salt.  The more agitated the water the quicker it will mix the calmer the longer it will sit on top.

Humph. Just can't resist it, can you: turn a fascinating natural phenomenon into sentimental fluff by dragging it down to the level of a daytime TV soap. Please, keep people out of it! "What this story needs is people!" someone cried. "Yeah! Personalities! Let's emphasise the human angle!"

No. No, don't do that. My unwanted invisible companion Doctor Asperger says that wouldn't be a good thing to do.

Sheesh! (Or possibly seiche?) Just show me the physics. Don't apologise for the technical nature of something technical and dilute it with great gobbets of uplifting human drama.
